I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the country programming mission in November 2011, the Government of the 
People's Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  the  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission (NDRC) in elaborating a comprehensive road map for the demonstration and 
deployment of carbon capture and storage (CCS)1 in the PRC including an in-depth techno-
economic  feasibility  assessment  of  the  oxy-fuel  combustion  carbon  dioxide  (CO )  capture 
2
technology.2 During a fact-finding mission in April 2012, the TA’s design, impact and outcome, 
methodology  and  key  activities,  scope,  cost estimates,  financing  plan,  and  implementation 
arrangements were agreed with NDRC and the Ministry of Finance. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  As  a  result  of  energy-intensive  economic  growth,  a  particularly  rapid  increase  in 
electricity demand, and heavy reliance on carbon-intensive coal in its energy mix, the PRC now 
accounts for about 20% of global primary energy and about half of global coal consumption.4 
The PRC is one of the world’s largest emitters of CO , the major greenhouse gas responsible 
2
for climate change TheInternational Energy Agency (IEA) estimates that 720 million tons (72%) 
.   
of the incremental 1 gigaton of CO  emissions globally in 2011 originated from the PRC. The 
2
government, during its Eleventh Five-Year Plan, 2006–2010, committed to reducing its energy 
intensity  by  20%5 and  promoting  rapid  development  of  renewable  energy.6 Without  this 
commitment,  the  IEA  estimates  that  the  PRC’s  emissions  in  2011  would  have  exceeded 
1.5 gigatons because of a much higher increase in coal consumption for power generation and 
by heavy industries. In 2009, the PRC committed to reducing its carbon intensity by 40%–45% 
by 2020, compared with 2005. Considering the latest emission trajectory, it is essential to fast-
track more effective decarbonization of economic growth, particularly in power generation and 
heavy industry output.7 
 
3.  The government’s Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015 emphasizes a “green, low-carbon 
development concept” with the targets of (i) increasing the proportion of non-fossil fuels in total 
energy consumption to 11.4%, and (ii) reducing carbon intensity by 17%. Notwithstanding, the 
PRC is expected to add large fossil-fuel-based power generation plants to meet the growing 
electricity demand and to sustain economic growth.8 Even with very strong incentives for energy 
efficiency, renewable and other low-carbon technologies, including nuclear power, coal is likely 
to remain a dominant part of the PRC’s energy mix until at least 2035. The urgent deployment of 
                                                 
1  The CCS is an integrated system of technologies involving (i) separation and capture of CO  from large emitting 
2
sources, (ii) compression of captured CO  and its transportation to a geological site, and (iii) injecting CO  in 
2 2
suitable geological formation underground for storage. Oxy-fuel combustion is one of the three main CO  capture 
2
technologies. Others are pre-combustion and post-combustion technologies.    
2  The TA is included as Oxy-fuel Combustion Carbon Capture for Power Plant and CCS Road Map for Industrial 
Applications in ADB. 2012. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2012–2014. Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 22 June 2012. 
4  In 2011, the PRC’s total energy consumption was 3.5 billion tons of coal equivalent. Coal accounted for about 70% 
of the primary energy consumption and 80% of the electricity consumption. Electricity consumption increased 
between 1990 and 2010 on average by 10% annually and to date nearly equals that of the United States. 
5  Energy intensity refers to energy consumption per unit of gross domestic product.  
6  During the Eleventh Five-Year-Plan period, the PRC (i) improved energy efficiency by 19.1%; (ii) increased the 
share of renewables in the total final energy consumption to 9%; and (iii) shut down 70 gigawatts (GW) of small, 
high-polluting coal-fired power plants. 
7  Carbon intensity is the amount of carbon by weight emitted per unit of energy consumed. 
8  The target capacity to be installed over the plan period is 530 GW, of which about 280 GW will be coal-based.

2  
the  full  range  of  low-carbon  technologies,  including  CCS,  is  essential  for  the  PRC  to 
decarbonize its power sector and achieve its long-term climate change mitigation goals. 
 
4.  CCS is currently the only available near-commercial system of technologies that can cut 
CO   emissions  from  fossil-fuel-based  power  plants  to  the  atmosphere  by  80%–90%.  It  is 
2
included  in  all  cost-effective  climate  change  mitigation  strategies  proposed  by  the 
Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and the IEA. To avoid catastrophic climate change 
impacts, global leaders at the 15th Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework 
Convention on Climate Change (COP 15) in Copenhagen in 2009 recognized the scientific view 
that global average temperature rise should be below 2 degrees Celsius (2°C). This requires 
CO  emissions to be halved by 2050 from their 2009 levels. According to the IEA, CCS could 
2
achieve about one-fifth of the desired reduction in the least-cost manner. At least 38 projects 
that fit CCS to power generation are required by 2020 to have an 80% chance of limiting the 
temperature rise to 2°C.9 The IEA estimates that the PRC alone would need to build 10–12 such 
projects by 2020. To date, no such plant is in operation anywhere in the world. 
 
5.  Since  2005,  the  government  has  supported  studies,  technology  research,  and  pilot 
projects as part of the national science and technology programs in cooperation with bilateral 
and multilateral development partners. By 2011, nine pilot projects were operational and the 
essential aspects of CCS demonstration had been studied. The National Program on Climate 
Change includes CCS demonstration as one important action. To date, various government 
agencies  and  energy  companies  have  published  their  road  maps,  each  emphasizing 
components of CCS demonstration. However, these efforts have so far not led to the realization 
of a demonstration project at scale. 
  
6.  The loan and TA projects that ADB provided to the government have mainly focused on 
pre-combustion carbon capture technology.10 They identified several key barriers to large-scale 
demonstration: (i) low policy priority of CCS; (ii) incomplete policy and regulatory framework; 
(iii) low fiscal and financial support for CCS demonstration projects compared with support for 
energy efficiency and renewable energy projects; (iv) inadequate international targeted funding 
mechanisms to support projects in emerging economies; (v) higher capital cost and auxiliary 
energy consumption, but no additional revenues; and (vi) technical challenges in scaling up 
these projects. These TA projects produced the following recommendations on how to remove 
barriers to early-stage demonstration projects: (i) targeted public funding and concessional 
financing should be available for such projects;11 (ii) a favorable tariff as applicable to other low-
carbon technologies in the power sector should be extended to CCS; and (iii) CCS policy for 
demonstration should focus on early-stage projects, including those projects that may utilize 
CO  before its geological sequestration. 
2
 
7.  The  key  conclusion  from  these  TA  projects  is  that  a  staged  approach  to  CCS 
demonstration and deployment is essential. Such an approach would entail the construction of

3
some early-stage demonstration projects where part of the higher cost is paid for by using the 
captured CO  for applications such as enhanced oil recovery.12 Utilization of captured CO  
2 2
before its storage is often referred to as carbon capture, utilization, and storage. Successful 
CCS application in these early-stage demonstration projects will provide valuable insights and 
key  learning  opportunities,  and  will  trigger  wider  CCS  demonstration  and  deployment.  A 
comprehensive road map with consistent policy targets, complemented with adequate policy 
instruments and support measures, is essential to guide CCS demonstration and deployment. 
Previous efforts in the PRC show that such a road map will only be effective in paving the way 
for CCS demonstration if it is steered by NDRC, the leading national energy and climate change 
policy-making body of the PRC. The TA will meet this key requirement. 
 
8.  Currently, two critical analytical gaps prevent formulation of a comprehensive road map 
and fast-tracking of CCS demonstration and deployment in the PRC. They concern (i) the role of 
the CCS-ready approach, and (ii) oxy-fuel combustion CO  capture technology. Regarding the 
2
first gap, ADB TA is being implemented to develop capacity on post-combustion CO  capture for 
2
natural-gas-based power plants using a CCS-ready approach to avoid carbon lock-in.13 It will 
also develop country-specific CCS-ready criteria and test those in a small-scale pilot project. It 
will be important to feed lessons learned into possible new standards for fossil-fuel-based power 
plants, which will directly add to the establishment of a comprehensive policy framework. As for 
the second gap, oxy-fuel combustion CO  capture technology has so far been tested in the PRC 
2
only  in  micro-scale  pilot  projects.14 Its  techno-economic  characteristics  have  not  yet  been 
studied sufficiently to assess its potential role in the mix of CO capture technologies in the PRC. 
2 
To avoid further carbon lock-in, necessary analyses and studies of oxy-fuel combustion CO  
2
capture technology will be undertaken in parallel to the elaboration of a comprehensive CCS 
road map as part of this TA. 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the government's priorities for developing a comprehensive CCS 
policy framework and road map for demonstration and deployment. It effectively responds to the 
urgent need to gain in-depth understanding of the techno-economic applicability of oxy-fuel 
combustion CO  capture technology, the remaining of the three main technologies to capture 
2
CO . This is a logical next step after ADB’s previous and ongoing CCS TA projects for analysis 
2
and in-depth understanding of the other two CO  capture technologies—pre-combustion capture 
2
from  coal-based  integrated  gasification  combined  cycle  power  plants  and  post-combustion 
capture from natural-gas-based power plants. The three studies will feed into comparisons 
(least-cost, cost–benefit, and unique application opportunities) between these technologies for a 
comprehensive CCS road map elaboration. 
 
10.  The TA is also aligned with ADB’s PRC country partnership strategy, 2011–2015, which 
prioritizes promoting environmentally sustainable growth, reducing carbon intensity, innovation 
and knowledge-based support for high-impact low-carbon technologies, and policy reforms to 
establish an enabling environment for investments in clean energy, which contribute to the 
global public good of mitigating climate change.15

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact will be the staged demonstration of carbon capture and storage in the PRC. 
The  outcome  will  be  the  assessed  techno-economic  feasibility  of  selected  early-stage 
demonstration projects. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will consist of two components: component A for formulating a road map for 
CCS demonstration and deployment, and component B for an oxy-fuel combustion CO  capture 
2
technology assessment. Component A will deliver the following outputs: (i) a comprehensive 
road map for demonstration and deployment of CCS; (ii) a recommended set of suitable policies 
and regulations, and an incentive framework; (iii) a shortlist and ranking of early-stage CCS 
demonstration projects; (iv) suitable business models for implementing early-stage projects; and 
(v) capacity strengthening measures in policy making, and techno-economic modeling for CCS 
road map.  
 
13.  Component B will deliver the following outputs: (i) pre-feasibility assessment of a coal-
fired  power  plant  applying  oxy-fuel  combustion  CO   capture  technology;  (ii)  established 
2
technical  standards  for  oxy-fuel  combustion  CO   capture  technology;  (iii)  a  CO   storage 
2 2
characterization manual; and (iv) capacity assessment and strengthening measures in analysis, 
planning, and implementation of oxy-fuel combustion CO  capture technology. 
2
 
14.  The major assumptions on project output, outcome, and impact are in Appendix 1. The 
TA design factors in critical risks and takes measures to mitigate them. It also defines the key 
lessons from earlier TA projects in the PRC addressing aspects of CCS development. The 
executing  and  implementing  agencies  are  directly  relevant  national  agencies  with  a  clear 
mandate to advance CCS. Nonetheless, CCS entails a complex system of technologies that are 
in the early stage of development and have still weak support from government and civil society. 
Some of the factored-in risks relate to the global dialogue on a new climate change treaty and 
availability of international finances to support early-stage CCS demonstration projects. But 
ADB's engagement with the developed countries through the Carbon Sequestration Leadership 
Forum and Clean Energy Ministers’ Action Group on Carbon Capture Utilization and Storage 
clearly  indicates  their  strong  desire  to  provide  financing  support  to  early-stage  CCS 
demonstration projects in the PRC.16 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,600,000, of which $2,200,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Carbon Capture and Storage Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership 
Facility.17 The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation and support facilities, studies, reports, data, and other in-kind contributions. 
The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
                                                 
16 In 2009, the Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute contributed A$21.5 million to establish a CCS Fund 
under ADB’s Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility. In April 2012, the United Kingdom announced £60 
million funding support for CCS development in developing and emerging countries.   
17 Established by the Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute and administered by ADB.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  NDRC, the government institution responsible for the formulation of energy and climate 
change policy, and approval of large-scale demonstration projects, will be the executing agency 
for the TA. The Center for Strategic Studies and International Cooperation on Climate Change, 
attached to NDRC, will be the implementing agency for component A, and Dongfang Boiler will 
be the implementing agency for component B.18 
 
17.  Component A will use individual consultants (5 international, 13 person-months; and 10 
national, 88 person-months). They will have in-depth knowledge of the PRC’s energy sector, 
including the oil, gas, coal-mining, power, and CCS subsectors, as well as the PRC’s energy 
policy. They will all have previous experience in elaborating road maps and designing energy 
policy proposals preferably in the PRC. The consulting inputs estimated for component B are 4 
international  consultants  for  12  person-months,  and  8  national  consultants  for  62  person-
months. The tasks under component B will be carried out by a consulting firm that will be 
engaged using the quality- and cost-based selection method (with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20). 
The firm will be required to submit a simplified technical proposal covering all aspects of the 
terms of reference. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The terms of reference for 
consultants for components A and B are in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  Procurement of TA-relevant equipment will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Ownership of this equipment 
will  be  transferred  to  the  relevant  executing  agency  and/or  implementing  agency  after  TA 
completion. TA funds will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months from 15 September 2012, with an expected 
completion date of 15 March 2014. The consultants will submit an inception report within 1 
month; three interim reports within 6, 10, and 12 months; a draft final report within 16 months; 
and the final report within 18 months of field mobilization.19 Information on the progress of 
implementation  and  on  TA  outputs  will  be  disseminated  through  regular  workshops  and 
seminars. The outcome of the TA will be subject to evaluation by both ADB and the government 
in accordance with their respective evaluation policies and requirements. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
20.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,200,000 to the Government of the People’s 
Republic of China to be financed on a grant basis by the Carbon Capture and Storage Fund 
under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility for the Road Map for Carbon Capture 
and Storage Demonstration and Deployment. 
                                                 
18 Dongfang Boiler is a major state-owned thermal power plant equipment supplier that specializes in developing oxy-
fuel combustion projects. It is currently working on a 30-megawatt pilot project. Thus, it has critical capacity and 
technical know-how to advance further analytical work on oxy-fuel combustion CO  capture technology and share 
2
them with other energy enterprises in the PRC.

1.  The policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) will be implemented under the overall 
supervision and oversight of the National Development and Reform Commission. Day-to-day 
coordination, guidance, and support will be provided by counterpart staff of the implementing 
agencies—Center for International Cooperation and Strategic Studies on Climate Change for 
component  A,  and  Dongfang  Boiler  for  component  B.  TA  implementation  will  be  closely 
coordinated with stakeholders, especially during the firming up of the TA outputs. 
 
A.  Component A 
 
2.  A group of individual consultants (international: 13 person-months; national: 88 person-
months) will provide the consulting services for component A. In addition, the TA will appoint an 
implementation  consultant  on  an  as  needed  basis  at  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
headquarters. The international consultants will have the full range of expertise required for 
steering the TA project. Each consultant will be responsible for finalizing their output in close 
coordination with the team and its leader.  
 
1.  International Consultants 
 
3.  Carbon capture and storage expert and team leader (3.5 person-months). The expert, 
in conjunction with the national deputy team leader, will coordinate the activities and act as focal 
point  for  interacting  with  stakeholders.  The  expert  should  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in 
engineering or another relevant field and at least 15 years of professional experience in the 
energy sector or the oil and gas industry, including at least 5 years of experience with work 
related to carbon capture and storage (CCS). With the support of and in conjunction with the 
team, the expert will be responsible for the following tasks: 
(i)  Conduct  a  comprehensive  situation  analysis  for  CCS  development  in  the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
(ii)  Prepare techno-economic analyses of early-stage CCS projects in high-emitting 
sectors. 
(iii)  Develop a short list of candidate early-stage CCS projects, screen them and 
establish a priority ranking. Prepare a blueprint for front-end engineering and 
design studies for such projects. 
(iv)  Determine  an  optimum  mix  of  low-carbon  technologies,  including  CCS,  to 
achieve the PRC’s emission reduction targets. 
(v)  Conduct source-sink matching based on pertinent studies and information. 
(vi)  Assess and recommend an effective and efficient mix of policies, regulations, 
fiscal, financial, and other mechanisms supporting CCS demonstration. 
(vii)  Recommend suitable business models for CCS demonstration. 
(viii)  Formulate a comprehensive CCS demonstration and deployment road map for 
the PRC. 
(ix)  Design and implement a capacity development program.

C.  Deliverables 
 
15.  The  consultants  engaged  for  component  A  will  each  have  individually  defined 
deliverables to be specified in their individual contracts. The reports will be submitted by the 
international consultants in conjunction with the national consultants. The international team 
leader in conjunction with the national co-team leader will have the overall responsibility for 
synthesizing the outputs from other experts in a coherent manner, and ensure the quality of the 
TA outputs. 
 
16.  The consulting firm to be engaged for component B will submit the following reports, 
each consisting of one copy in English for ADB and two copies in Chinese for the executing 
agency and the government. The expected deliverables of the consulting services include but 
are not limited to the following:  
(i)  Inception report. The report will be submitted within 1 month after the TA starts. 
It will summarize the initial findings and suggest any changes needed in the TA 
approach, methodology, and time schedule. 
(ii)  Interim  draft  reports.  These reports will be submitted within 6, 10, and 12 
months after the TA starts. 
(iii)  Draft final report. The draft will be submitted within 16 months after the TA 
starts. The draft final report will include all components required in the study and 
it will cover all aspects of the TA implementation. 
(iv)  Stakeholder  consultation  workshops. One workshop will be held after the 
preparation of the inception report; an interim workshop and one final workshop 
will be held to engage stakeholders in the road-mapping exercises, promote the 
exchange  of  ideas,  collect  comments,  and  increase  ownership  of  and 
commitment to the TA recommendations. 
(v)  Final  report.  This  will  be  submitted  within  1  month  after  the  consultation 
workshop. The consultants will incorporate comments from the stakeholders in 
the final report. An executive summary will also be submitted. 
(vi)  Facilitation of steering committee meetings. The steering committee meetings 
will be held ad interim in connection with stakeholder workshops on call of the 
National Development and Reform Commission. 
(vii)  TA implementation workshops. An inception workshop will be organized after 
engagement of all TA consultants, and the midterm review and final workshops 
will be combined with the consultation and final workshops listed in items 16 (iv) 
and 16 (vi).
